Hi Darcy,

Thank you for the frank comments.  I think you are right concerning 
discussions of valuation -- subjective, hard to do without the piece 
in hand, and can cause unintended results.  I apologise to you, 
especially, and to any other member who was bothered by my naive 
observations.

Your expanded description will help me alot in appreciating this 
blade, and in my self-designed home study course - Nihonto 101, 
Introduction to the Japanese Sword.  Which somebody should offer at 
my local community college or Japanese culture center.  

Thank you again.  I will try to listen [read] more and speak 
[comment] less.  

Doug

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, samurai@x wrote:
> 
> Hi Doug,
> 
> The tanto is mine. It is indeed in shirasaya, and also has Tanobe
> sensei's sayagaki on it. 
> 
> You hit on a lot of items why it is a collectable piece. There are 
a lot
> of activities in the hamon too, making it a good study sword, and of
> course it is also representative of its times. 
> 
> The horimono are not etched as was previously suggested by the 
question
> asker. Horimono like this are carved. Naotsuna are often found with
> bohi, but horimono like this are quite rare on his works, and there 
are
> very few tanto by this smith (none are signed).
> 
> There are three mekugi ana most likely on this tanto because it has 
gone
> into three different sets of fittings (or more) over its lifetime. 
That,
> and the frequent polishing, would likely point to this as being a 
well
> used weapon, rather than something that spent most of its life as an
> object of adoration. Those are my guesses at it.
> 
> For the original poster, in terms of the high end Soshu smiths, this
> represents entry-level price, so the question is more one of what is
> holding this one back from higher prices I would think. The hamon is
> still lively on this tanto, but it is at the point where I wouldn't 
want
> to put one, or two more polishes on it. That is pretty much the only
> thing against it in my book, but then there are others who have
> different tastes in school, smith, period, and type.
> 
> - darcy
> 
> <ashigaru1@y...> writes:
> 
> > While described as being slightly "tired" this tanto has much 
going 
> > for it.  Soshu style -- not all that common; ubu; student 
> > [atribution, school of] of not only a good smith, but a student 
of 
> > Masamune -- considered the O-Kaji -- if i can make up a word -- 
the 
> > master of master smiths.  His work is almost never signed, and it 
is 
> > not surpising his student's swords were not either.  He worked 
for 
> > the Shogun of the Kamakera Bankafu thus would not usually sign 
his 
> > name as a relatively indendent smith might. It has good paper. In 
> > good polish.  And since they do not say, I assume it is delivered 
in 
> > shirasaya.  Being a newcomer to Nihon-to myself, that is about 
all I 
> > got.  I am sure the more Knowledgable members can expand upon, or 
> > correct, my comments.
> 
> > One question for the group:  Why the three mekugie ana?  
> 
> > Doug
